description.narrative: The Programme facilitates access by GBV survivors to quality GBV response and prevention services, and ensures GBV survivors are empowered to break the cycle of abuse

participating-org.narrative: MPTF-Phase Il GRZ-UN Joint Programme on Gender-Based Violence in Zambia

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

provider-org.narrative: MPTF-Phase Il GRZ-UN Joint Programme on Gender-Based Violence in Zambia
MPTF-Phase Il GRZ-UN Joint Programme on Gender-Based Violence in Zambia

MPTF-Phase Il GRZ-UN Joint Programme on Gender-Based Violence in Zambia

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
The Project has the following outcome and output indicators: Outcome 1: GBV Survivors and persons (including children and adolescents) at risk have increased access to and utilize quality GBV prevention and response Outcome Indicator 1.1: % of women and girls who reported experiencing any form of Gender Based Violence (GBV) who sought help to stop the violence - Indicator data needs to be collected through a short survey Outcome Indicator 1.2a: % of eligible survivors receiving PEP within 72 hrs. - Indicator data needs to be collected through a short survey Outcome Indicator 1.2b: % of eligible survivors receiving EC within 72 hours - Indicator data needs to be collected through a short survey Outcome Indicator 1.3: % of GBV survivors receiving legal assistance Outcome Indicator 1.4: % of survivors receive services at hospital based OSCs either from other parts of the health facilities, other service providers and/or the community Outcome Indicator 1.5:% of GBV cases before and through the Fast-Track Courts resolved within 3 months out of the total annual GBV cases before and through the Fast-Track Courts.
Outcome 2: GBV Survivors, those at risk and communities are able to break the cycle of abuse
Outcome Indicator 2.1: % of GBV survivors and those at risk aged 15-49 taking up employment opportunities (Self/wage) (Disaggregated by age and sex) Outcome Indicator 2.2: # of GBV survivors and those at-risk reporting increase in economic empowerment Outcome Indicator 2.3: % of currently married women whose husbands make decisions about their health care for them - Indicator information will be collected through short survey Outcome Indicator 2.4: % change in women/ men aged 15-49 who agree that a husband is justified in hitting or beating his wife for at least one reason Indicator data information needs to be collected through a short survey Output Indicators Output 1 - Target Districts have increased capacity to deliver co-ordinated GBV services Indicator 1.1 -

comment.narrative:
The Project M&E Results Framework has the following baseline outcome and output indicator data: Outcome 1: GBV Survivors and persons (including children and adolescents) at risk have increased access to and utilize quality GBV prevention and response Outcome Indicator 1.1: % of women and girls who reported experiencing any form of Gender Based Violence (GBV) who sought help to stop the violence - Indicator data needs to be collected through a short survey Outcome Indicator 1.2a: % of eligible survivors receiving PEP within 72 hrs. - Indicator data needs to be collected through a short survey Outcome Indicator 1.2b: % of eligible survivors receiving EC within 72 hours - Indicator data needs to be collected through a short survey Outcome Indicator 1.3: % of GBV survivors receiving legal assistance - 13% Outcome Indicator 1.4: % of survivors receive services at hospital based OSCs either from other parts of the health facilities other service providers and/or the community - 0 Outcome Indicator 1.5:% of GBV cases before and through the Fast-Track Courts resolved within 3 months out of the total annual GBV cases before and through the Fast-Track Courts. 66%
Outcome 2: GBV Survivors, those at risk and communities are able to break the cycle of abuse
Outcome Indicator 2.1: % of GBV survivors and those at risk aged 15-49 taking up employment opportunities (Self/wage) (Disaggregated by age and sex) . This indicator needs to be established through a short survey Outcome Indicator 2.2: # of GBV survivors and those at-risk reporting increase in economic empowerment - 0 Outcome Indicator 2.3: % of currently married women whose husbands make decisions about their health care for them - Indicator information will be collected through short survey Outcome Indicator 2.4: % change in women/ men aged 15-49 who agree that a husband is justified in hitting or beating his wife for at least one reason Indicator data information needs to be collected through a short survey Output In

During 2020 the following were the targets: Outcome 1: GBV Survivors and persons (including children and adolescents) at risk have increased access to and utilize quality GBV prevention and response Outcome Indicator 1.1: % of women and girls who reported experiencing any form of Gender Based Violence (GBV) who sought help to stop the violence - 0% Outcome Indicator 1.2a: % of eligible survivors receiving PEP within 72 hrs. - 0% Outcome Indicator 1.2b: % of eligible survivors receiving EC within 72 hours - Indicator data needs to be collected through a short survey Outcome Indicator 1.3: % of GBV survivors receiving legal assistance - 10% Outcome Indicator 1.4: % of survivors receive services at hospital based OSCs either from other parts of the health facilities other service providers and/or the community - 20% Outcome Indicator 1.5:% of GBV cases before and through the Fast-Track Courts resolved within 3 months out of the total annual GBV cases before and through the Fast-Track Courts. 70%
Outcome 2: GBV Survivors, those at risk and communities are able to break the cycle of abuse
Outcome Indicator 2.1: % of GBV survivors and those at risk aged 15-49 taking up employment opportunities (Self/wage) (Disaggregated by age and sex) . This indicator needs to be established through a short survey - 0 Outcome Indicator 2.2: # of GBV survivors and those at-risk reporting increase in economic empowerment - 0 Outcome Indicator 2.3: % of currently married women whose husbands make decisions about their health care for them - Indicator information will be collected through short survey - 200 Outcome Indicator 2.4: % change in women/ men aged 15-49 who agree that a husband is justified in hitting or beating his wife for at least one reason Indicator data information needs to be collected through a short survey - 200 Output Indicators Output 1 - Target Districts have increased capacity to deliver co-ordinated GBV services Indicator 1.1 - # of hospital based One Stop Centres (OSC) established and functional in the project districts - 0 Indicator 1.2 # of hospital based One Stop Centres strengthened in the project districts - 0 Indicator 1.3 - # of community structures conducting dialogues and info sessions on GBV services and prevention - 10 Indicator 1.4 - # of OSCs which are child friendly - 0 Indicator 1.5 - # of service providers trained on multi-disciplinary GBV guidelines (disaggregated by type of service provider and sex) - 130 Output Indicator 1.6: # of Minimum Standards and Guidelines developed for GBV service providers and facilities for operationalization of GBV shelters and VLOSC - 0 Output Indicator 1.7: # of Community Response Mechanisms (VLOSC) Established - 0 Output Indicator 1.8: # of people accessing services at the Community Response Mechanisms (VLOSC) - 120. Output 2 - GBV survivors have increased access to safe shelters, and child victims of violence have care plans in place and access to family based alternative care settings Indicator 2.1 - # of survivors that benefit from specialized services at the GBV shelters - 139 Indicator 2.2 - # of Anti-GBV shelters established for temporary housing of GBV survivors - 1 Indicator 2.3 -# of shelters strengthened for temporary housing of GBV survivors - 4 Output 2.4 - # of child GBV survivors supported to access alternative care options through case management - 88 Output 3 - Target districts have increased capacity to deliver quality legal services Indicator 3.1 - # of Fast-Track Courts (FTCs) established - 0 Indicator 3.2 - % of FTCs that are operating in line with child friendly standards - 0 Indicator 3.3 - # of legal service providers trained - 50 Indicator 3.4 - # of GBV survivors provided with legal services - 1000 Output 4 - GBV survivors and those at risk access economic empowerment services Indicator 4.1 - # of GBV survivors and those at risk capacitated in business development - 0 Indicator 4.2 - # of GBV survivors and those at risk provided with enterprise (Income Generation Activities) start-up support. - 0 Indicator 4.3 - # of GBV survivors and those at risk engaged in saving and credit groups - 0 Indicator 4.4 - : # of saving and credit groups (formal/informal) supported to start/improve enterprises (Income Generating Activities). - 0 Indicator 4.5: - # of ICT Hubs Established - 0 Indicator 4.6 - # of women and girls capacitated with ICT knowledge - 200 Output 5.0 - Community and traditional leadership structures have capacity to mobilize on GBV prevention Indicator 5.1 - # of traditional leaders sensitized on GBV and COVID-19.- 1,513 Indicator 5.2 - # of spouses of traditional leaders ’ sensitized on GBV and COVID-19 -500 Indicator 5.3: - # of religious leaders sensitized on GBV and COVID-19 - 100 Indicator 5.4:- # of political leaders sensitized on GBV and COVID-19 - 60 Indicator 5.5: - # of people participating in community structures reached with GBV/COVID-19 prevention and response messages.- 2000 Indicator 5.6: - # of community structures mobilized to challenge norms and cultural practices that sanction and perpetuate GBV and the low status of women and persons with disability - 0 Output 6 - Improved multi-sectoral coordination and governance related to GBV prevention and response Indicator 6.1 - # of district plans mainstreaming GBV - 0 Indicator 6.2 - # of policies/legal instruments/guidelines finalized - 2 Indicator 6.3 - : # of service delivery points tracking GBV data on an MIS.- 0 Indicator 6.4 - : # of Steering Committee meetings held -2 Indicator 6.5 - # of Joint monitoring missions - 4 Indicator 6.6 - # of Joint planning and review meetings held -2

During 2020 the following were the results/achievements: Under Output 1 - Target Districts have increased capacity to deliver co-ordinated GBV services Indicator 1.1 - 10 hospital based One Stop Centres (OSC) established strengthened/established and functional in the project districts, 2 of which are VLOSC Indicator 1.2 - 35 community structures conducting dialogues and info sessions on GBV services and prevention Indicator 1.3 - 0 OSCs which are child friendly Indicator 1.4 - 429 service providers trained on multi-disciplinary GBV guidelines (disaggregated by type of service provider and sex)
Output 2 - GBV survivors have increased access to safe shelters, and child victims of violence have care plans in place and access to family based alternative care settings Indicator 2.1 - 74 GBV survivors housed in project supported shelters Indicator 2.2 - 7 shelters strengthened for temporary housing of GBV survivors, 0 refurbished/rehabilitated Indicator 2.3 - 29 child GBV survivors supported to access alternative care options through case management Output 3 - Target districts have increased capacity to deliver quality legal services Indicator 3.1 - 6 of Fast-Track Courts (FTCs) strengthened, 0 FTCs constructed and functional Indicator 3.2 - 0 - % of FTCs that are operating in line with child friendly standards Indicator 3.3 - 486 legal service providers trained Indicator 3.4 - 130 GBV survivors provided with legal aid
Output 4 - GBV survivors and those at risk access economic empowerment services ndicator 4.1 - 569 GBV survivors and those at risk capacitated in business development Indicator 4.2 - 319 GBV survivors and those at risk provided with enterprise start up support Indicator 4.3 - 0 GBV survivors and those at risk engaged in savings and credit groups Indicator 4.4 - 0 savings and credit groups (formal and informal) supported to start/improve Indicator 4.4 - 35 women and girls capacitated with ICT knowledge Output 5 - Community and traditional leadership structures have capacity to mobilise on GBV prevention Indicator 5.1 - 567 traditional, religious, and political leaders and spouses sensitised on GBV Indicator 5.2 - 158,102 people participating in community structures trained on GBV prevention (disaggregated by type of structure, age and sex) Output 6 - Improve multi-sectoral co-ordination and governance related to GBV prevention and response Indicator 6.1 - 20 district plans mainstreaming GBV Indicator 6.2 - 2 policies/guidelines finalised Indicator 6.3 - 2 service delivery points tracking GBV data on an MIS Indicator 6.4 - 2 Project Steering Committees Held Indicator 6.5 - 7 joint review and planning meetings held (3 physical 4 virtual)

During 2021 the following were the targets: Outcome 1: GBV Survivors and persons (including children and adolescents) at risk have increased access to and utilize quality GBV prevention and response Outcome Indicator 1.1: % of women and girls who reported experiencing any form of Gender Based Violence (GBV) who sought help to stop the violence - 15% Outcome Indicator 1.2a: % of eligible survivors receiving PEP within 72 hrs. - 15% Outcome Indicator 1.2b: % of eligible survivors receiving EC within 72 hours - Indicator data needs to be collected through a short survey Outcome Indicator 1.3: % of GBV survivors receiving legal assistance - 10% Outcome Indicator 1.4: % of survivors receive services at hospital based OSCs either from other parts of the health facilities other service providers and/or the community - 35% Outcome Indicator 1.5:% of GBV cases before and through the Fast-Track Courts resolved within 3 months out of the total annual GBV cases before and through the Fast-Track Courts. 75%
Outcome 2: GBV Survivors, those at risk and communities are able to break the cycle of abuse
Outcome Indicator 2.1: % of GBV survivors and those at risk aged 15-49 taking up employment opportunities (Self/wage) (Disaggregated by age and sex) . This indicator needs to be established through a short survey - 350 Outcome Indicator 2.2: # of GBV survivors and those at-risk reporting increase in economic empowerment - 350 Outcome Indicator 2.3: % of currently married women whose husbands make decisions about their health care for them - Indicator information will be collected through short survey - 150 Outcome Indicator 2.4: % change in women/ men aged 15-49 who agree that a husband is justified in hitting or beating his wife for at least one reason Indicator data information needs to be collected through a short survey - 150 Output Indicators Output 1 - Target Districts have increased capacity to deliver co-ordinated GBV services Indicator 1.1 - # of hospital based One Stop Centres (OSC) established and functional in the project districts - 0 Indicator 1.2 # of hospital based One Stop Centres strengthened in the project districts - 2 Indicator 1.3 - # of community structures conducting dialogues and info sessions on GBV services and prevention - 10 Indicator 1.4 - # of OSCs which are child friendly - 2 Indicator 1.5 - # of service providers trained on multi-disciplinary GBV guidelines (disaggregated by type of service provider and sex) - 130 Output Indicator 1.6: # of Minimum Standards and Guidelines developed for GBV service providers and facilities for operationalization of GBV shelters and VLOSC - 1 Output Indicator 1.7: # of Community Response Mechanisms (VLOSC) Established - 3 Output Indicator 1.8: # of people accessing services at the Community Response Mechanisms (VLOSC) - 180. Output 2 - GBV survivors have increased access to safe shelters, and child victims of violence have care plans in place and access to family based alternative care settings Indicator 2.1 - # of survivors that benefit from specialized services at the GBV shelters - 141 Indicator 2.2 - # of Anti-GBV shelters established for temporary housing of GBV survivors - 1 Indicator 2.3 -# of shelters strengthened for temporary housing of GBV survivors - 4 Output 2.4 - # of child GBV survivors supported to access alternative care options through case management - 91 Output 3 - Target districts have increased capacity to deliver quality legal services Indicator 3.1 - # of Fast-Track Courts (FTCs) established - 0 Indicator 3.2 - % of FTCs that are operating in line with child friendly standards - 60% Indicator 3.3 - # of legal service providers trained - 50 Indicator 3.4 - # of GBV survivors provided with legal services - 1300 Output 4 - GBV survivors and those at risk access economic empowerment services Indicator 4.1 - # of GBV survivors and those at risk capacitated in business development - 350 Indicator 4.2 - # of GBV survivors and those at risk provided with enterprise (Income Generation Activities) start-up support. - 200 Indicator 4.3 - # of GBV survivors and those at risk engaged in saving and credit groups - 150 Indicator 4.4 - : # of saving and credit groups (formal/informal) supported to start/improve enterprises (Income Generating Activities). - Output Indicator 1.1.3: 773 service providers were trained on multi-disciplinary GBV Guidelines Output Indicator 1.2.3: Eight (8) shelters strengthened by for temporary housing of GBV survivors through provision of supplies and office accessories Output Indicator 1.2.4 179 child GBV survivors were supported to access alternative care options through case management Output Indicator 1.3.4: 87 GBV survivors provided with legal aid Output Indicator 2.1.2: 836 GBV survivors and those at risk capacitated in business development Output Indicator 2.1.2: 336 (310 females, 26 males) GBV survivors and those at risk provided with enterprise (Income Generating Activities) start up support Output 2.1.6:300 women and girls capacitated with ICT knowledge Output Indicator 2.2.5: 4, 158 people participating in community structures trained on GBV/COVID-19 prevention Output Indicator 2.3.5: 19 Joint planning and review meetings held
Project implementation started in December 2019. So during 2019 not much was done apart from initialising the Project
The GRZ-UN JP GBV II Project was intitialised during December 2019

During 2022 the following are the targets: Outcome Indicator 1.1: % of women and girls (15-49 years) who reported experiencing physical or sexual violence who sought help to stop the violence: Lusaka 42.9%, Muchinga 36.6%, Northern 39.8%, N/Western 46.9% Southern 54.5% and Western 60.7% Outcome Indicator 1.2 % of eligible survivors receiving PEP within 72 hrs - 20% Outcome Indicator 1.3: % of GBV survivors receiving legal assistance - 5% Outcome Indicator 1.4: % of survivors linked to hospital based OSCs. - 35% Outcome Indicator 1.5: % of GBV cases resolved within 3 months before and through the Fast-Track Courts as a proportion of total annual GBV cases before and through FTCs - 80%
